form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mrs. Hyde-Smith (for herself, Mr. Risch, Mr. Lankford, Mr. Kennedy, Mr. Hawley, Mr. Mullin, Mr. Daines, Mr. Barrasso, Mr. Lee, and Mr. Cramer) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

form.official-title: To prohibit the Federal Government from conducting, funding, approving, or otherwise supporting any research involving human fetal tissue that is obtained pursuant to an induced abortion, and to prohibit the solicitation or knowing acquisition, receipt, or acceptance of a donation of such tissue.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Protecting Life and Integrity in Research Act of 2025.

section.header: No research involving human fetal tissue obtained pursuant to an induced abortion

paragraph.text: No Federal department, agency, or office may conduct, fund, approve, or otherwise support any research involving human fetal tissue that is obtained pursuant to an induced abortion.

paragraph.header: Development of new, ethical cell lines
paragraph.text: Subsection (a) does not limit the authority of the head of any Federal department, agency, or office, to develop or support the development of new, high-efficiency cell lines, including for the production of vaccines and genetic vectors, so long as the cell lines are not derived from human fetal tissue that is obtained pursuant to an induced abortion.

paragraph.header: Research involving human fetal tissue obtained after a miscarriage or stillbirth permitted
paragraph.text: Any research of any Federal department, agency, or office on human fetal tissue obtained after a miscarriage or stillbirth shall be conducted or supported in accordance with section 498A of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 289g–1).
In this subsection, the term human fetal tissue has the meaning given such term in section 498A(g) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 289g–1(g)).

subsection.header: Amendments to the PHSA limiting human fetal tissue research to tissue obtained after a miscarriage or stillbirth
subsection.text: Section 498A of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 289g–1) is amended—

paragraph.text: in the section heading, by striking transplantation of fetal tissue and inserting human fetal tissue obtained after a miscarriage or stillbirth;
by amending subsection (a) to read as follows:

subsection.text: The Secretary may conduct or support research on human fetal tissue obtained after a miscarriage or a stillbirth.

subparagraph.text: in paragraph (1)(B), by inserting if the human fetal tissue is intended for transplantation, before the donation; and

clause.text: by redesignating subparagraphs (B) and (C) as subparagraphs (A) and (B), respectively;

paragraph.text: in subsection (c)(1)(B), by striking pursuant to a spontaneous or induced abortion or pursuant to and inserting after a miscarriage or; and
by amending subsection (g) to read as follows:
The term human fetal tissue means tissue or cells obtained from a dead unborn child pursuant to an induced abortion, a miscarriage, or a stillbirth.
The term miscarriage means the involuntary death of an unborn child who was carried in the womb for a period of less than 20 weeks.
The term stillbirth means the involuntary death of an unborn child who was carried in the womb for a period of 20 weeks or more.
-The term unborn child has the meaning given such term in section 1841(d) of title 18, United States Code.

subsection.text: Section 113 of the National Institutes of Health Revitalization Act of 1993 (42 U.S.C. 289g–1 note) is repealed.

section.header: Prohibition against solicitation or knowing acquisition, receipt, or acceptance of a donation of human fetal tissue knowing that the tissue was obtained pursuant to an induced abortion

subsection.text: Paragraph (1) of section 498B(c) of the Public Health Service Act (42 U.S.C. 289g–2(c)) is amended to read as follows:

paragraph.text: solicit or knowingly acquire, receive, or accept a donation (excluding any transfer for purposes of autopsy or burial) of human fetal tissue knowing that—

subparagraph.text: a human pregnancy was deliberately initiated to provide such tissue; or
the tissue was obtained pursuant to an induced abortion; or

paragraph.text: by redesignating subsections (c) through (e) as subsections (b) through (d), respectively; and
